                          <div class="the-article-layout__article-body-wrapper">
                <div class="the-article-layout__article-body the-article-layout__article-body--with-image-nojs js-the-article-layout__article-body--with-image">
                                      <div class="the-article-layout__article-image the-article-layout__article-image--nojs js-the-article-layout__article-image">
                      <div class="panel-pane pane-views-panes pane-breaking-news-images-panel-pane-1  view-mode-teaser"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div data-module="breaking_news_images-panel_pane_1" class="view view-breaking-news-images view-id-breaking_news_images view-display-id-panel_pane_1 view-dom-id-f1bb37572e71dd349cc75d30a3aa34bc">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-breaking-news-images">        <div class="field-content"><img class="img-responsive" src="https://student-ui.prd.timeshighereducation.com/sites/default/files/styles/the_breaking_news_image_style/public/istock-179019842.jpg?itok=rHD4Qf7I" width="620" height="413" alt="Road map of United Kingdom, close up on London" title="Road map of United Kingdom, close up on London" /></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-file-image-credit">        <div class="field-content">Source: iStock/gianlucamuscelli</div>  </div>  </div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div>  </div>

  
  </div>
                    </div>
                                    <div class="panel-pane pane-entity-field pane-node-field-body"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-body field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cuts to degree subjects across the UK are preventing thousands of young people studying social sciences, humanities or arts in their region, new analysis has found.Â </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As <a data-mz="" data-module="breaking_news-body" data-position="body" href="https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/student-choice-risk-almost-half-universities-cut-courses">universities close courses and departments</a> in response to financial pressures, the British Academy has warned that students in parts of the North, South West and East of England, as well as large areas of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, are losing access to social sciences, humanities and arts (SHAPE) courses.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Analysis found that large parts of the UK â€“ often rural, coastal or historically underserved regions â€“ are already â€œcold spotsâ€ for provision in many of these subjects, with none offered within a commutable distance of 60 kilometres or less, despite the fact that more students than ever are now studying close to home.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><a data-mz="" data-module="breaking_news-body" data-position="body" href="https://www.thebritishacademy.ac.uk/policy-and-research/british-academy-shape-observatory/cold-spots-mapping-inequality-in-shape-provision/">The academyâ€™s latest report</a> notes that cuts in these subject areas are particularly pronounced within institutions that require lower grades â€“ often those catering to students from disadvantaged backgrounds.Â </span></p><html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><body><div id="div-gpt-in-article-ad-3-mobile" data-ad-position="the_dfp_in_article_ad" data-ad-size="[300,250]" data-ad-priority="high" data-ad-unit="21841059662/THE_COM/academic/article" data-ad-page="news" class="the-dfp the-dfp__in-article js-the-dfp__in-article the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile js-the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile"><div class="before-ad-container-label-article">ADVERTISEMENT</div></div></body></html>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">â€œDecisions to cut courses are often a reaction to short-term projections of student demand, with quick fixes coming at the cost of strategic vision and longer-term viability,â€ the report warns.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">â€œBut leaving what is taught in our universities solely up to market forces undermines resilient subject provision and economic strategy, with lasting consequences for students and for universitiesâ€™ ability to serve a public good.â€</span></p><html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><body><div id="div-gpt-in-article-ad-5-desktop" data-ad-position="the_dfp_in_article_ad" data-ad-size="[300,250]" data-ad-priority="high" data-ad-unit="21841059662/THE_COM/academic/article" data-ad-page="news" class="the-dfp the-dfp__in-article js-the-dfp__in-article the-dfp__in-article-preload--desktop js-the-dfp__in-article-preload--desktop"><div class="before-ad-container-label-article">ADVERTISEMENT</div></div></body></html>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Provision in modern foreign languages has nearly halved since 2011-12, while studies in linguistics, anthropology, classics, and theology are vulnerable â€œin many UK regionsâ€, the report says.Â </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">More SHAPE subjects â€“ including English, history and drama â€“ are at risk if trends continue, it adds.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">â€œThese cold spots have far-reaching consequences, limiting opportunities for students, weakening pipelines into teaching, research and key growth sectors, damaging local and national economies, and eroding the UKâ€™s global reputation for academic excellence,â€ the report notes.Â </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sarah Cowan, head of policy at the British Academy, said debates in recent years about the â€œvalue of studying social sciences and humanitiesâ€ were partially to blame for these declines, as well as the growing financial pressures on universities.</span></p><html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><body><div id="div-gpt-in-article-ad-9-mobile" data-ad-position="the_dfp_in_article_ad" data-ad-size="[300,250]" data-ad-priority="low" data-ad-unit="21841059662/THE_COM/academic/article" data-ad-page="news" class="the-dfp the-dfp__in-article js-the-dfp__in-article the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile js-the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile"><div class="before-ad-container-label-article">ADVERTISEMENT</div></div></body></html>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When institutions are forced to â€œmake really difficult decisions about their own future and sustainability, the obvious choice to make is to look at degrees which perhaps have falling numbers orâ€¦are under attack in the press,â€ she said.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">However, she continued, research suggests SHAPE graduates have similar levels of career success to science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) graduates, while the sectors highlighted in the governmentâ€™s Industrial Strategy â€œhave really high proportions of SHAPE graduates in their employmentâ€.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The report calls on regulators to monitor subject-level provision more closely through an â€œat riskâ€ regional subject register and â€œat riskâ€ subject premium.Â </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It also urges the government to issue â€œclear guidanceâ€ on competition laws to enable better collaboration between institutions â€“ something that could emerge in Labourâ€™s <a data-mz="" data-module="breaking_news-body" data-position="body" href="https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/dont-expect-funding-reform-plan-skills-white-paper-v-cs-told">upcoming post-16 skills White Paper</a>.</span></p><html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><body><div id="div-gpt-in-article-ad-13-desktop" data-ad-position="the_dfp_in_article_ad" data-ad-size="[300,250]" data-ad-priority="low" data-ad-unit="21841059662/THE_COM/academic/article" data-ad-page="news" class="the-dfp the-dfp__in-article js-the-dfp__in-article the-dfp__in-article-preload--desktop js-the-dfp__in-article-preload--desktop"><div class="before-ad-container-label-article">ADVERTISEMENT</div></div></body></html>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The British Academy has called for a full review of the higher education funding system, warning that, without a sustainable system, SHAPE cold spots will deepen and other subjects will be further affected.Â </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">â€œI think one of the worst things that we could end up with is [a] piecemeal sticking plaster approach,â€ such as increasing fees slightly, Cowan said. â€œIt either stops things from getting worse without fixing them, or it just pushes the issue further down.â€</span></p><html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><body><div id="div-gpt-in-article-ad-15-mobile" data-ad-position="the_dfp_in_article_ad" data-ad-size="[300,250]" data-ad-priority="low" data-ad-unit="21841059662/THE_COM/academic/article" data-ad-page="news" class="the-dfp the-dfp__in-article js-the-dfp__in-article the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile js-the-dfp__in-article-preload--mobile"><div class="before-ad-container-label-article">ADVERTISEMENT</div></div></body></html>
<p><em><span style="font-weight: 400;"><a data-mz="" data-module="breaking_news-body" data-position="body" href="mailto:helen.packer@timeshighereducation.com">helen.packer@timeshighereducation.com</a></span></em></p></div></div></div>  </div>

readabilityObject.title: Humanities and arts degrees disappearing in parts of UK
readabilityObject.content:
Cuts to degree subjects across the UK are preventing thousands of young people studying social sciences, humanities or arts in their region, new analysis has found. 

As universities close courses and departments in response to financial pressures, the British Academy has warned that students in parts of the North, South West and East of England, as well as large areas of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, are losing access to social sciences, humanities and arts (SHAPE) courses.

Analysis found that large parts of the UK â€“ often rural, coastal or historically underserved regions â€“ are already â€œcold spotsâ€ for provision in many of these subjects, with none offered within a commutable distance of 60 kilometres or less, despite the fact that more students than ever are now studying close to home.

The academyâ€™s latest report notes that cuts in these subject areas are particularly pronounced within institutions that require lower grades â€“ often those catering to students from disadvantaged backgrounds. 

â€œDecisions to cut courses are often a reaction to short-term projections of student demand, with quick fixes coming at the cost of strategic vision and longer-term viability,â€ the report warns.

â€œBut leaving what is taught in our universities solely up to market forces undermines resilient subject provision and economic strategy, with lasting consequences for students and for universitiesâ€™ ability to serve a public good.â€

Provision in modern foreign languages has nearly halved since 2011-12, while studies in linguistics, anthropology, classics, and theology are vulnerable â€œin many UK regionsâ€, the report says. 

More SHAPE subjects â€“ including English, history and drama â€“ are at risk if trends continue, it adds.

â€œThese cold spots have far-reaching consequences, limiting opportunities for students, weakening pipelines into teaching, research and key growth sectors, damaging local and national economies, and eroding the UKâ€™s global reputation for academic excellence,â€ the report notes. 

Sarah Cowan, head of policy at the British Academy, said debates in recent years about the â€œvalue of studying social sciences and humanitiesâ€ were partially to blame for these declines, as well as the growing financial pressures on universities.

When institutions are forced to â€œmake really difficult decisions about their own future and sustainability, the obvious choice to make is to look at degrees which perhaps have falling numbers orâ€¦are under attack in the press,â€ she said.

However, she continued, research suggests SHAPE graduates have similar levels of career success to science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) graduates, while the sectors highlighted in the governmentâ€™s Industrial Strategy â€œhave really high proportions of SHAPE graduates in their employmentâ€.

The report calls on regulators to monitor subject-level provision more closely through an â€œat riskâ€ regional subject register and â€œat riskâ€ subject premium. 

It also urges the government to issue â€œclear guidanceâ€ on competition laws to enable better collaboration between institutions â€“ something that could emerge in Labourâ€™s upcoming post-16 skills White Paper.

The British Academy has called for a full review of the higher education funding system, warning that, without a sustainable system, SHAPE cold spots will deepen and other subjects will be further affected. 

â€œI think one of the worst things that we could end up with is [a] piecemeal sticking plaster approach,â€ such as increasing fees slightly, Cowan said. â€œIt either stops things from getting worse without fixing them, or it just pushes the issue further down.â€

helen.packer@timeshighereducation.com
